"One-vote majority rulings carry the same legal weight as all majority opinions. Yet they lack the symbolic power of decisions by a more united court. Experts consider these 5-to-4 decisions to be more expressly political than others, representing a threat to the court's moral authority....
 
 "The Roberts Court has relied on 5-to-4 majorities to pass many of its headline decisions: from this weeks ruling that the Second Amendment guarantees an individual's right to gun ownership to the Lilly Ledbetter case, limiting an employee's ability to file a pay discrimination claim, to the Citizens United decision, which allowed unlimited corporate and union spending in elections....
 
 "Studies show that 5-to-4 decisions are the most likely rulings to be overturned by later Supreme Courts. 
 
 "But the deeper issue transcends any one case or court. The 'supreme' authority of the high court rests on its legitimacy. The more absent consensus is from the high court, the more diminished its legitimacy and the more each decision will come to be viewed through a political lens."

 Actually government regulation of weapons goes back much farther than the Minutemen.
 
 The Assize of Arms was an English law enacted in 1181 under King Henry II. The law specified who had to own weapons (at the owner's expense), but it also specified the kinds of weapons that had to be owned as well as the number of each kind. The great bulk of the population were excluded from the law and thus could not legally own weapons -lest they go on a crime spree or rebel against the government), and the people that could own weapons had to provide military service, swear allegiance to the King and could only own the weapons that the law specifically said they could own- lest they go on a crime spree or rebel against the government. You did not have a right to have or be part of a private army or other military force not under the government's control and you did not have a right to engage in armed rebellion against duly constituted government.
 
 Some people tried to tell the U.S. Supreme Court in District of Columbia v. Heller that the Assize of Arms granted a right to bear arms, but the Court did not use it as precedence in issuing the decision. The Court did cite the English Bill of Rights of 1689 as precedence for a right to bear arms under U.S. law. However, the Court's ruling must have been some kind of convoluted since the English Bill of Rights did not specifically recognize the right of an individual person to own weapons- and Roman Catholics (as was the case with Jews under the Assize of Arms) were forbidden to be armed at all.

 An early Virginia colonial law granted everyone a right to sell arms and ammunition to "any of His Majesty's loyal subjects inhabiting this colony..."- meaning nobody had a right to use armed force against the colony's legitimate government. A right to bear arms is not a right to rebel.
 
 A mid-17th century Virginia law restricted how guns could be used. There was to be no shooting when drinking (and presumably pot-smoking?) unless you were at a wedding or funeral (the same thing to a lib?) because firing a gun was the common alarm signal for an Indian attack.
 
 A 1680 Virginia law prohibited slaves and other black people from having weapons. And even when this law was changed in 1723 due to the large population of free blacks and Indians living in the colony the law still limited gun ownership to 1 gun per person and that person had to be a householder. Any black or Indian who was not a householder or otherwise on the muster rolls of the government's militia was required by law to turn get rid of their guns by the end of 1723. Any black or Indian living on the frontier could own a gun if they got a license from the government. And by 1738 the law was once again changed so that blacks and Indians could not own guns even if they were part of the militia.
 
 A 1735 South Carolina law authorized the search of slave quarters for guns and no slave or free black could then own a gun without getting a license from the government. 
 
 So, the right to bear arms has never been as absolute as the libs claim.

You seem to miss something very important. The Founding Fathers had to deal personally with a corrupt tyrant of a king who ran a kangaroo court in whatever manner he decided fit, so long as he was exempt from any and all laws. This tyrant sent his armed forces to disarm the people of Lexington And Concord and confiscate all found weapons.
 
 Having lived through all of this, why would the Founding Fathers -people who escaped oppression and fought so hard for freedom- set up a system that would make it impossible for the people to defeat a local tyrant that emerged from the government?

 Because they had confidence in the system of government they set up with its checks and balances. They had confidence that their system of government was fundamentally different from what they experienced under the British. Samuel Adams, one of the original Sons of Liberty who rebelled against the British in Boston, said: 
 
 "Rebellion against a king may be pardoned, or lightly punished, but the man who dares to rebel against the laws of a republic ought to suffer death."
 
 Here are some examples of government authority over firearms in early America:
 
 -In Anglo-American law, the state may exercise extraordinary powers and even abridge basic civil liberties like the right to a trial, at moments of military emergency. The practice of impressment [confiscation of private property for public use] is, like the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, an application of the state's military power.... Of ten states that practiced the impressment of arms during the Revolution, eight appear to have permanently discontinued the practice by 1787.
 
 -Almost thirty years ago, Edmund Morgan observed that white Virginians excluded African-Americans, Indians, and indentured servants from the body politic and denied them the most fundamental of rights. In 1998, Michael Bellesiles applied this observation to the issue of gun ownership, demonstrating that most colonial jurisdictions denied these groups the right to keep weapons.
 
 - When called upon by the Continental Congress to disarm non-associators, legislatures enacted a series of measures that ordered the disarmament of those refusing to take up arms against the king.
 
 -Pennsylvania's Test Act of 1777 marks the return to voluntary allegiance as the standard of membership in the body politic. It required all white men over eighteen to swear an oath declaring allegiance to the commonwealth, abjuring all allegiance to the British monarchy, and promising to do nothing injurious to the freedom and independence of the state. The act prohibited those refusing the test from voting, holding office, serving on juries, suing, and transferring land. It also ordered them disarmed.
 
 - Maryland instituted a test oath in 1777 and barred those refusing from the basic civil liberties of voting, holding office, serving on juries, suing, and keeping arms.
 
 - North Carolina followed suit, barring non-testors from basic liberties including the keeping of arms while promising that any who relented would be "held and deemed a good subject of this state, and shall enjoy the privileges thereof."
 
 - Early American militia laws prohibited any use of guns on the day of muster unless expressly ordered by militia officers. They also required militiamen and other householders to bring their guns to the muster field twice a year so that militia officers could record which men in the community owned guns. Some colonies authorized door-to-door surveys of gun ownership.
 
 - Colonial governments expressed particular concern over the firing of guns after dark, in part because the traditional method of raising the alarm of an attack after dark involved the firing of several guns in succession. Thus, an amendment to New Hampshire's militia law prohibited the firing of guns after sunset during "time of war or watch." Connecticut and Georgia enacted similar measures.
 
 - By 1770, the shooting of guns was prohibited in the cities of Philadelphia, New York, and Boston. The colonies of Pennsylvania and New York extended this prohibition to all other towns and boroughs. Delaware also prohibited the firing of guns within built-up areas, but made an exception for "days of public rejoicing."
 
 - Rhode Island banned the placement of shooting ranges lying across a public highway. Pennsylvania banned gunfire "on or near any of the King's highways." The legislature noted, however, that the fine did not extend "to any person carrying a gun on the public highway." New Jersey also explicitly protected the carrying of guns on the highways.
 
 - Massachusetts regulated the manner of keeping arms as well as the manner of using them. As a precaution against the accidental wounding of firefighters, the state prohibited the storage of loaded guns in any house within the town of Boston. At least some of these laws, including the prohibition of storing loaded guns in Boston, provided for the confiscation of the gun as penalty. North Carolina and New Jersey both acted to prevent trespasses by hunters and to preserve their game populations by levying steep fines for abusive hunting practices. Each colony also provided that hunters without a "settled habitation" or residence in the colony would forfeit their guns.
 Robert H. Churchill | Forum: Rethinking the Second Amendment: Gun Regulation, the Police Power, and the Right to Keep Arms in Early America: The Legal Context of the Second Amendment | Law and History Review, 25.1 | The History Cooperative

We made it, and if we wish to do so then it's supposed to be in our power to completely dismantle it any way we see fit. That's why we say "of the people, by the people and for the people".
flaja

Nope. Wrong again. Nothing in the Constitution grants authority to the government to form a private army made of any state militia, to be used as a hammer to smite another militia that rises up due to concerns of local tyranny.

 
 Have you even read the Constitution? It doesn't look like it.
 
 U.S. Constitution
 Article I
 Section 8
 
 "The Congress shall have Power...To provide for calling forth the Militia to execute the Laws of the Union, suppress Insurrections and repel Invasions; To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining the Militia, and for governing such Part of them as may be employed in the Service of the United States, reserving to the States respectively, the Appointment of the Officers, and the Authority of training the Militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress..."
 
 U.S. Constitution
 Article I
 Section 10
 
 "No State shall, without the Consent of Congress...keep
 Troops, or Ships of War in time of Peace, enter into any Agreement or Compact with another State, or with a foreign Power, or engage in War, unless actually invaded, or in such imminent Danger as will not admit of delay."
NATO 556

Show me exactly where in the Constitution it says that the government may usurp authority from the people and subjugate them to the status of slaves, and kill anyone that attempts to resist.
 
 According to your argument, anybody who exercises their First Amendment right of holding a public protest against government action, may be treated as an enemy of the state and met with force.

 According to your argument, anybody who exercises their First Amendment right of holding a public protest against government action, may be treated as an enemy of the state and met with force.

 
 This is not what I have said.
 
 Amendment I
 Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or
 prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or
 of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.
 
 You do not have a right to use violence of any kind as a tool for exercising any constitutional right. If you use violence to exercise your rights you forfeit your rights because you have made yourself an enemy of society and this gives the government the authority to punish you as an enemy.
NATO 556

You do not have a right to use violence of any kind as a tool for exercising any constitutional right. If you use violence to exercise your rights you forfeit your rights because you have made yourself an enemy of society and this gives the government the authority to punish you as an enemy.

 
 Oh really?
 
 The Supreme Court has ruled, in Heller and again in McDonald, that we have a constitutional right to defend ourselves against harm. Are you saying that in order to defend ourselves we're not allowed to use violence against those that would harm us?
 
 You'd better not be arguing that kind of bull****, that's straight out of Britain. Britain says you might have a right to protect yourself but you're not allowed to cause any degree of harm to the person attacking you. You knock them down and you're automatically the aggressor and they're the victim.
flaja

Oh really?
 
 The Supreme Court has ruled, in Heller and again in McDonald, that we have a constitutional right to defend ourselves against harm. Are you saying that in order to defend ourselves we're not allowed to use violence against those that would harm us?

 
 Yes really.
 
 You either cannot read or cannot listen because the Heller decision does not grant or otherwise recognize any individual or collective right to use armed force against the government. The Heller decision only declares individuals have a right to own and use firearms for traditional legal purposes. Treason for some may be a tradition, but it has never been legal. The Court ruled that like most rights "the Second Amendment is not unlimited. It is not a right to keep and carry any weapon whatsoever in any manner whatsoever and for whatever purpose."
 
 You forfeit your right to self-defense against harm when you violate the law. By your warped standards a bank robber has a right to kill the cops that chase him because he may suffer harm if they catch him. 
 
 
You'd better not be arguing that kind of bull****, that's straight out of Britain. Britain says you might have a right to protect yourself but you're not allowed to cause any degree of harm to the person attacking you. You knock them down and you're automatically the aggressor and they're the victim.

NATO 556

You either cannot read or cannot listen because the Heller decision does not grant or otherwise recognize any individual or collective right to use armed force against the government. The Heller decision only declares individuals have a right to own and use firearms for traditional legal purposes.

 
 Obviously you're the one who can neither read nor listen, if you can't understand that protecting oneself against loss of life, property or liberty IS a legal purpose!
 
 
Treason for some may be a tradition, but it has never been legal. The Court ruled that like most rights "the Second Amendment is not unlimited. It is not a right to keep and carry any weapon whatsoever in any manner whatsoever and for whatever purpose."

 
 The only ones who could be charged for treason is the government in such a case, not the people. The people have a right to resist all enemies, foreign AND domestic. And when the government turns against the people and has them scared to death of it, it has become tyrannical in nature and needs to be dealt with accordingly.
 
 You really need to learn how to understand basic concepts. There's absolutely nothing in the Constitution that elevates the government to a state of being above the people. The Constitution is there to control and regulate the powers of government, not the people it's supposed to serve. Government works for us, it does what we tell the elected officials, and if they disobey they lose their jobs in the next election.
 
 The Founding Fathers escaped a corrupt tyrant to seek out a better life. I find it impossible to believe that having gone through all of this, they would take absolutely no steps to prevent their new republic from following the same course that made them flee in the first place.
 
 
You forfeit your right to self-defense against harm when you violate the law.

 
 The right to self defense is as ancient as the human race. It's not forfeited by the people just because the use of force or violence is used against someone else.
 
 If somebody is threatening the life of myself, a loved one, or a complete stranger, that individual will be neutralized, through absolutely any means necessary. Injury, coma or outright death, it's up to them on which they wish to suffer in the commission of their crime.
 
 
By your warped standards a bank robber has a right to kill the cops that chase him because he may suffer harm if they catch him.

 
 You criticize my argument, and then turn around and make a statement such as this?
 
 Robbery is an illegal act, there's no legal protection to it. The bank robber has absolutely no claim to simply defending himself against the police. It's by no means comparable to protecting yourself against someone trying to harm you.
 
 
Documentation?

 
 Myleene Klass warned by police after scaring off intruders with knife - Telegraph
 
 Hudson Institute < Self-Defense Under Attack in Britain

Obviously you're the one who can neither read nor listen, if you can't understand that protecting oneself against loss of life, property or liberty IS a legal purpose!

 
 Not when you have violated the law and thus given the government legal cause to come after you. And even if it is not the government that is about to do you harm, you don't have a right to use deadly force as a first resort- which I get the impression you are aching to do.
 
 You've wasted enough of my time for today, so save your rants for later and return to your cabin in the woods.

Not when you have violated the law and thus given the government legal cause to come after you.

 
 Then show me exactly where it's written, that we as citizens of the United States, have absolutely no recourse other than to lay down and take it when the government decides to mistreat us and regard us as potential enemies that threaten its existence.
 
 Show us the part of the Constitution that spells out our enslaved status, guaranteeing government full authority to regulate the people in any manner it sees fit.
 
 
And even if it is not the government that is about to do you harm, you don't have a right to use deadly force as a first resort

 
 Actually we do. With the exception of a few communist locations in the United States, we're under no obligation whatsoever to first flee our attacker, even going as far as to leave our own home, before we can turn and fight. We have no duty to preserve the life of the bad guy at the expense of our own. In many states a person can deploy deadly force if they believe it's necessary to prevent imminent harm.
 
 
You've wasted enough of my time for today, so save your rants for later and return to your cabin in the woods.

 
 You don't get to dismiss those that you disagree with.

I have and I didn't.

 
 Then you obviously didn't look hard enough to understand.
 
 
When and where have I said that We the People must put up with anything and everything the government wants to do? When? Where?

 
 Look up the part about "suppressing insurrections". Insurrection is the open rebelling against government policy, refusing to just lay down and take whatever the government tells you you're going to take whether you like it or not. The way you spin it you're saying those who exercise their First Amendment rights are dangerous rebels that need to be suppressed through military force.
 
 Just look at how many people are on the no fly list, and for reasons that nobody anywhere understands. This entire post 9/11 to find possible threats, no matter how small, is a perfect example of the government exercising tyranny and using fear as a weapon against the people. You can be investigated without notice or warrant so long as it's in the name of "fighting terrorism", even though no proof of potential terrorist ties has to be presented. 
 
 Basic human rights no longer apply because you might have some remote connection to an organization in Kuwait. You can be held indefinitely without trial or formal charges because you might be a potential terrorist. You know that fact as well as anybody.
 
 Did you consider that simple fact when you cited Section 8?
 
 
When and where have I said that We the People don’t have any constitutional recourse when the government does something that We the People don’t want? When? Where?

 
 When you said that the people don't have a right to rebel.
 
 Take a look at the Obamacare bill that got rammed through, despite overwhelming public opposition for it. Under the law you're forced under threat of punishment to obtain health insurance, even if you don't want or need it. You have no opt out provision, and if you try you get fined every single year until you finally surrender and do as you're told like a good little dog.
 
 If we can't rebel against Obamacare because that's illegal, and if we can't opt out of it's mandatory coverage clause even though it violates our basic right of choice, exactly what options do you have left other than lay down and take it because the masters tell you to?
 
 You really didn't think out your argument before you made it, did you?
Galileo

Supposed quotes from Founding Fathers that the cabin-in-the-woods types spout in support of a right to armed rebellion are a dime a dozen. Looking on the net, you can easily get the impression that not one single Founding Father had any respect for the rule of law. I am glad to see someone finally post something to counter the libertarians’ ignorance and stupidity.
 

 That quote from Samuel Adams is a reaction to the Shays rebellion. 
 Shays' Rebellion
 
 George Washington's reaction was,
 "I am mortified beyond expression when I view the clouds that have spread over the brightest morn that ever dawned in any country... What a triumph for the advocates of despotism, to find that we are incapable of governing ourselves and that systems founded on the basis of equal liberty are merely ideal and fallacious."
 
 In contrast, Thomas Jefferson's reaction was,
 "A little rebellion now and then is a good thing. It is a medicine necessary for the sound health of government. God forbid that we should ever be twenty years without such a rebellion.... The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots & tyrants. It is it's natural manure. ."
 http://etext.virginia.edu/etcbin/ot2www-singleauthor?specfile=/web/data/jefferson/texts/jefall.o2w&act=text&offset=5674387&textreg=1&query=tree+of+liberty
 
 Jefferson's quote, also known as the tree of liberty quote, seems to be the only quote that you hear unless you are willing to dig deeper into the matter. Jefferson wasn't even in the US at the time. He was in Europe. The quote was his reaction to hearing about rebellion that he was a safe distance from. Despite this, pro-gun/libertarian/pro-anarchy type groups seem to love this quote even though most of the Founding Fathers' reaction to the Shay's Rebellion was the polar opposite. Timothy McVeigh wore this quote from Jefferson on his shirt the day he bombed the federal building. I like studying real history and trying to put things things in proper context rather than just using history to serve a current political agenda. The original tea party was a protest against taxation without representation. Ironically, tea baggers in our own day do have representation in government but that doesn't stop them from using a historical event to advance their own agenda.
flaja

Jefferson's quote, also known as the tree of liberty quote, seems to be the only quote that you hear unless you are willing to dig deeper into the matter.

 
 Jefferson is a great favorite of self-proclaimed conservatives on the net, i.e., libertarians. But Jefferson's idea of perpetual rebellion is anathema to real conservatives.
 
 
I like studying real history and trying to put things things in proper context rather than just using history to serve a current political agenda. 

 
 Fortunately Jefferson did not attend the Constitutional Convention, and that document has given the country far more stability that Jefferson would have wanted or the Signers could have hoped for. It would do us a world a good if the net's "conservatives" would study Shays' Rebellion and get some idea about how much terror that event struck in the hearts of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention.
 
 
The original tea party was a protest against taxation without representation. Ironically, tea baggers in our own day do have representation in government but that doesn't stop them from using a historical event to advance their own agenda.

 
 The original Tea Party could have derailed our move towards independence because respectable leaders of society (people like George Washington) were appalled by the event since the end result was the destruction of private property. I don't remember all of the details, but there was an effort to raise money and compensate the British East India Company that owned the tea (despite the fact that the British Parliament demanded that the Colonists pay for the tea).
 
 And don't forget that John Adams served as defense counsel at the trial of the soldiers who where were charged with killing the American protesters at the Boston Massacre. Adams wanted to show the world that the unfolding American Revolution was not a rebellion against the rule of law.

 It's a simple fact that delegates, from time to time, need to be made afraid of the people who are affected by the laws they pass. They have to be reminded, effectively, about the people who put them into office, and who will take them out of office if they're upset.
 
 It's a simple fact that if the government doesn't fear the people, the ones who're really in charge of the country and who made the government in the first place, then what you have is a climate of the people being afraid of the government, which is more akin to a dictatorship.
 
 Do you really want a dictatorship state?
